g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
First, we wanted to establish a qualiﬁed dataset. For all variables related to soil temperature
and for any given month to be included, there had to be at least 20 days of daily records for that
month. This criterion reduced the number of stations to 360. For any month, if the calculated average
A) (1962–2011) for that month by at least three times
A, that value was treated as an outlier and was replaced by the average of
the three nearest stations for that month and year. However, the three nearest stations need to be as
evenly distributed as possible. After this quality check, for any daily or monthly mean, the annual
50) values of soil temperature were used for the following assessments.
Secondly, the monthly air temperatures and other meteorological variables across China had their
quality directly tested by the China Meteorological Administration due to their high quality. Hence, we
just used the monthly air temperatures and other meteorological variables data in the same 360 stations
in order to be consistent with soil temperature data. We also deﬁned
mean surface soil temperature and mean air temperature. In essence,
Finally, to assess the spatial patterns of temperature changes, China was divided into 50 regions
grid. The data from individual stations contained within each region were averaged to
calculate the regional and national mean values.
The trends for the change in every variable (
DTR, SD, h, V, p and
) across 360 stations were estimated by the Mann–Kendall test and a simple
linear regression using monthly mean values. For each season, namely winter (Dec–Feb), spring
(Mar–May), summer (Jun–Aug), and autumn (Sept–Nov), the seasonal mean soil temperature was
calculated ﬁrst from those three months before seasonal trends were obtained. Annual trends were
similarly calculated, with seasonal trends based on the monthly average soil temperatures.
cients (SAS statistical software, liner, SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA) were
calculated between the soil temperature variables and other climate variables, including SD, p, h, and

variables and SDTR to eliminate the e
ects of any interaction among variables on SDTR.

increase during spring. Therefore, the annual decrease in SDTR was primarily attributed to the large
decrease in winter. This dominant influence of winter on DTR is consistent with previous studies [
